captions.text: I have a lot of respect for the Fantasy Peasant Village economic model. It seems like those guys have
got a good scam going on. First you accidentally build your settlement within easy walking
distance of the local gnoll encampment or dragon cave or directly on top of a gateway
to hell, then all you have to do is build a big fat checkpoint in the village square
TORCHLIGHT is an action RPG in which you play one of three adventurers who arrive at a small town that went for the build directly on top of Satan option,

The graphic style owes a lot to World of Warcraft but while World of Warcraft continually expands the standard array of character classes into one huge mess that about as easy to keep balanced as a stilt walker with one leg on a treadmill Torchlight takes the Dragon Age route of boiling them down back to the big three the warrior the melee class looking
strongly like Bing Reims, the alchemist, the skinny white dude who fills the role of mage,
warlock, shaman and everything else where you don't actually have to do any physical
work, and a pair of big titties filling in for the rogue, and since this is a fantasy
game, big titties apparently do the exact opposite of what they do in the real world,
that is they make you more dexterous and skilled in the use of bows and long range weapons
without even smacking you across the chops every time you pull the string back.
The customization is extremely intuitive. There isn't any. So unless you happen to be Bing
Rames, don't expect to roleplay much.
Torchlight is a Steam game, currently exclusive to PC, and I wouldn't hold your breath for
a console port, it would lose a lot of the atmosphere of the original since you wouldn't
be able to hear your mouse button clicking about fifty times a second. This is something
the game has in common with Diablo, along with absolutely fucking everything else. You
click around town, click your way into some quests, click down to the dungeons, click
all the enemies to death, and then click back home again. There's more clicks than a school
for dolphin telegraph operators. You'd think clicking on an enemy would indicate you want
to smack them about until they die, but your character assumes you want to give them a
I definitely feel like I have a chance to say they're sorry, and you have to click
again for each smack, a bad habit I assumed had been bred out of RPGs.
The other reason why you probably won't see a console port is because we need to wait
for a console with fifty buttons and a controller the size of the tea tray.
With all the number keys assigned to different skills and having to switch between two functions

for each mouse button the controls aren exactly streamlined Excuse me but can we have a little better 3 or something bro I dunno It just way too much to watch Phrase three of the fucking loading screen hints to tell me how to get rid of it At first I played as a warrior on Normal difficulty and the first thing I discovered is that Torchlight
is big on Hordes.
Large numbers of enemies tend to gather around you, each picking at your Ving Rhames shaped
arse like a swarm of guinea pigs wielding toothpicks.
Fortunately by the end of the first dungeon I had a couple of clearing attacks that sent
the guinea pigs flying like a little furry firework.
Holy shit, I exclaimed, I am so fucking bored.
And I haven't used a single health potion despite having collected 37.
Apparently Torchlight interprets normal difficulty as normal for someone who has spent most of
their life chained to a basement wall.
So I restarted as an alchemist on hard difficulty.
Perhaps the guinea pigs would pose a greater challenge to my skinny white scholarly body.
I imagine they would have done if they'd been able to get near it, but my area and
effect spells and summoned minions kept them at bay.
Ten hours later I'd sold about twenty times as many health potions as I'd actually used
and acquired a spell called Giant Laser Beam Face Melty Death that gave the enemies even
less of a chance.
It did eat up mana like nobody's business, but I was practically brushing my teeth with
mana potion at that stage.
There was one thing that gave me difficulty, for want of a better, more profane word, and
That's NPC pathfinding. Perhaps this is another reason why most of the NPCs spend
their whole lives standing perfectly still, because they get easily confused by any movement
more complex than walking in a straight line. My class choice meant I had a constant entourage
of imps and robots, and I lost count of how many times I'd emerge from an unusually difficult

battle to find that half my assistants were fifty feet back attempting to navigate their way through a footeye wall Besides them every character gets either a dog or a cat in another testament to the phrase
Spoiled for choice, whose job is to hold spare armour and weapons and take them to the service to sell them for you to the surprisingly unconcerned shopkeepers.
It doesn't take long to realise how necessary this is. Monsters constantly drop equipment, most of which needs to be identified in the most egregious example of needless busywork,
